1.title: Everything is at its Acme
1.body: This is especially true of the art of making one's way in the world. There is more required nowadays to make a single wise person than formerly to make the Seven Sages of ancient Greece, and more is needed nowadays to make a single person than was required with a whole people in former times.

2.title: Character and Intellect
2.body: The two poles of our capacity; one without the other is but halfway to happiness. Intellect sufficeth not, character is also needed. On the other hand, it is the fool's misfortune to fail in obtaining the position, the employment, the neighbourhood, and the circle of friends that suit him.

3.title: Keep Matters for a Time in Suspense
3.body: Admiration at their novelty heightens the value of your achievements. It is both useless and insipid to play with your cards on the table. If you do not declare yourself immediately, you arouse expectation, especially when the importance of your position makes you the object of general attention. Mix a little with everything, and the very mystery arouses veneration. And when you explain, do not be too explicit, just as you do not expose your inmost thoughts in ordinary conversation. Cautious silence is the sacred sanctuary of worldly wisdom. A resolution declared is never highly thought of - it only leaves room for criticism. And if it happens to fail, you are doubly unfortunate. Besides, you imitate the divine way when you inspire people to wonder and watch.

4.title: Knowledge and Courage
4.body: These are the elements of greatness. Because they are immortal, they bestow immortality. Each is as much as he knows, and the wise can do anything. A person without knowledge is in a world without light. Wisdom and strength are the eyes and hands. Knowledge without courage is sterile.

5.title: Create a Feeling of Dependence
5.body: It is not he that adorns but he that adores that makes a divinity. The wise person would rather see others needing him than thanking him. To keep them on the threshold of hope is diplomatic, to trust to their gratitude is boorish; hope has a good memory, gratitude a bad one. More is to be got from dependence than from courtesy. He that has satisfied his thirst turns his back on the well, and the orange once squeezed fall from the golden platter into the waste basket. When dependence disappears good behavior goes with it, as well as respect. Let it be one of the chief lessons of experience to keep hope alive without entirely satisfying it, by preserving it to make oneself always needed, even by a patron on the throne. But do not carry silence to excess or you will go wrong, nor let another's failing grow incurable for the sake of your own advantage.

6.title: A Man at his Highest Point
6.body: We are not born perfect: every day we develop in our personality and in our calling till we reach the highest point of our completed being, to the full round of our accomplishments, of our excellences. This is known by the purity of our taste, the clearness of our thought, the maturity of our judgment, and the firmness of our will. Some never arrive at being complete âˆ’ something is always wanting; others ripen late. The complete man, wise in speech, prudent in act, is admitted to the familiar intimacy of discreet persons, is even sought for by them.

9.title: Avoid the Faults of your Nation

11.title: Cultivate those who can teach you

13.title: Act sometimes on Second Thoughts, sometimes on First Impulse

14.title: The Think Itself and the Way it is done

19.title: Arouse no Exaggerated Expectations on entering

22.title: A Man of Knowledge to the Point

25.title: Know how to take a Hint

30.title: Have naught to do with Occupations of Ill-repute

31.title: Select the Lucky and avoid the Unlucky

32.title: Have the Reputation of being Gracious

35.title: Think over Things, most over the most Important

36.title: In Acting or Refraining, weigh your Luck

37.title: Keep a Store of Sarcasms, and know how to use them

39.title: Recognise when Things are ripe, and then enjoy them

43.title: Think with the Few and speak with the Many

45.title: Use, but do not abuse, Cunning

54.title: Know how to show your Teeth

61.title: To Excel in what is Excellent

63.title: To be the First of the Kind is an Excellence

68.title: It is better to help with Intelligence than with Memory

69.title: Do not give way to every common Impulse

77.title: Be all Things to all Men

82.title: Drain Nothing to the Dregs, neither Good nor Ill

88.title: Let Your Behaviour be Fine and Noble

91.title: Never set to work at Anything if you have any Doubts of its Prudence

94.title: Keep the extent of your Abilities unknown

100.title: A Man without Illusions, a wise Christian, a philosophic Courtier

101.title: One half of the World laughs at the other, and Fools are they all

102.title: Be able to stomach big slices of Luck

103.title: Let each keep up his Dignity

108.title: The Path to Greatness is along with Others

110.title: Do not wait till you are a Sinking Sun

115.title: Get used to the Failings of your Familiars

121.title: Do not make a Business of what is no Business

125.title: Do not be a Black Lister of Faults

126.title: Folly consists not in committing Folly, but in not hiding it when committed

133.title: Better Mad with the rest of the World than Wise alone

135.title: Do not nourish the Spirit of Contradiction

136.title: Post Yourself in the Center of Things

138.title: The Art of letting Things alone

140.title: Find the Good in a Thing at once

142.title: Never from Obstinacy take the Wrong Side because your Opponent has anticipated you in taking the Right One

143.title: Never become Paradoxical in order to avoid the Trite

144.title: Begin with Another's to end with your Own

145.title: Do not show your wounded Finger

146.title: Look into the Interior of Things

149.title: Know how to put off Ills on Others

150.title: Know how to get your Price for Things

152.title: Never have a Companion who casts you in the Shade

153.title: Beware of entering where there is a great Gap to be filled

154.title: Do not Believe, or Like, lightly

155.title: The Art of getting into a Passion

157.title: Do not make Mistakes about Character

162.title: How to triumph over Rivals and Detractors

163.title: Never, from Sympathy with the Unfortunate, involve Yourself in their Fate

166.title: Distinguish the Man of Words from the Man of Deeds

167.title: Know how to take your own Part

168.title: Do not indulge in the Eccentricities of Folly

169.title: Be more careful not to Miss once than to Hit a hundred times

170.title: In all Things keep Something in Reserve

172.title: Never contend with a Man who has nothing to Lose

173.title: Do not be Glass in Conversation, still less in Friendship

174.title: DO not live in a Hurry

176.title: Have Knowledge, or know those that have Knowledge

177.title: Avoid becoming too familiar in Discourse

179.title: Reticence is the Seal of Capacity

180.title: Never guide the Enemy to what he has to do

181.title: The Truth, but not the whole Truth

182.title: A Grain of Boldness in Everything

183.title: Do not hold your Views too firmly

185.title: Never stake your Credit on a single Cast of the Die

187.title: Do pleasant Things Yourself, unpleasant things through Others

191.title: Do not take Payment in Politeness

193.title: Watch him that begins with Another's to end with his Own

194.title: Have reasonable Views of Yourself and of your Affairs

197.title: Do not carry Fools on your Back

199.title: TO find a proper Place by Merit, not by Presumption

201.title: They are all Fools who seem so besides half the rest

202.title: Words and Deeds make the Perfect Man

203.title: Know the great Men of your Age

204.title: Attempt easy Tasks as if they were difficult, and difficult as if they were easy

205.title: Know how to play the Card of Contempt

206.title: Know that there are vulgar Natures everywhere

208.title: Do not die of the Fools' Disease

209.title: Keep Yourself free from common Follies

210.title: Know how to play the Card of Truth

212.title: Keep to Yourself the final Touches of your Art

214.title: Do not turn one Blunder into two

215.title: Watch him that acts on Second Thoughts

218.title: Never act from Obstinacy but from Knowledge

219.title: Do not pass for a Hypocrite

220.title: If you cannot clothe yourself in Lionskin use Foxpelt

221.title: Do not seize Occasions to embarrass Yourself or Others

224.title: Never take Things against the Grain

227.title: Do not be the Slave of First Impressions

231.title: Never let Things be seen half-finished

232.title: Have a Touch of the Trader

233.title: Let not the proffered Morsel be distasteful

234.title: Never trust your Honour to another, unless you have his in Pledge

236.title: Make an Obligation beforehand of what would have to be a Reward afterwards

237.title: Never share the Secrets of your Superiors

238.title: Know what is wanting in Yourself

241.title: Put up with Mockery, but do not practice it

243.title: Do not be too much of a Dove

246.title: Never offer Satisfaction unless it is demanded

247.title: Know a little more, Live a little less

248.title: Do not go with the latest Speaker

249.title: Never begin Life with what should end it

251.title: Use human Means as if there were no divine ones, and divine as if there were no human ones

252.title: Neither belong to Yourself nor entirely to Others

254.title: Never despise an Evil, however small

255.title: Do Good a little at a time, but often

257.title: Never let Matters come to a Rupture

258.title: Find someone to share your Troubles

259.title: Anticipate Injuries and turn them into Favours

260.title: We belong to none and none to us, entirely

261.title: Do not follow up a Folly

263.title: Many Things of Taste one should not possess oneself

265.title: Set those under you difficult Tasks

266.title: Do not become Bad from sheer Goodness

268.title: The Wise does at once what the Fool does at last

269.title: Make use of the Novelty of your Position

270.title: Do not condemn alone that which pleases all

271.title: In every Occupation if you know little stick to the safest

272.title: Sell Things by the Tariff of Courtesy

273.title: Comprehend their Dispositions with whom you deal

275.title: Join in the Game as far as Decency permits

276.title: Know how to renew your Character

281.title: Find Favour with Men of Sense

282.title: Make use of Absence to make youself more esteemed and valued

286.title: Do not become responsible for all or for every one

289.title: Nothing depreciates a Man more than to show he is a Man like other Men

290.title: 'Tis a piece of Good Fortune to combine People's Love and Respect

292.title: Let your personal Qualities surpass those of your Office

295.title: Do not Affect what you have not effected

297.title: Act always as if your Acts were seen

298.title: Three Things go to a Prodigy

300.title: In one word, be a Saint
